Compatibility issues: Ensuring that all components are compatible with each other can be a challenge, as different manufacturers may have different standards and specifications.
Cost: Building a computer from scratch can be expensive, especially if you want high-quality components. Finding affordable options that still meet your needs can be difficult.

Lack of technical knowledge: Building a computer from scratch requires a certain level of technical knowledge and expertise. If you don't have the necessary skills, you may struggle to assemble the computer correctly or troubleshoot any issues that may arise.

Time-consuming: Building a computer from scratch can be time-consuming, especially if you are new to the process. It may take several hours or even days to complete, depending on the complexity of the build.
Risk of damage: Handling electronic components can be risky, and there is always a chance that you may damage something during the assembly process. This can be costly to repair or replace.
